feedback_items.title: Establish Screen Layout and Loading States
feedback_items.why_it_matters: When a screen is blank, users assume the app has crashed or failed to load. Providing immediate visual feedback through placeholders or spinners keeps users engaged while data is being fetched.
what_to_do: Implement a Scaffold or FrameLayout to hold screen content
Add a ProgressBar (Circular) to the center of the screen for initial data loading
Create an 'Empty State' view with an icon and text for when no data is available
Use Shimmer effect placeholders to represent loading content items

code_example.description: Show a loading spinner while data is being fetched

feedback_items.wireframe_changes: Add a ProgressBar in the center of the screen. When data loads, replace it with a vertical list of cards and a Top App Bar with the screen title.

feedback_items.title: Implement Standard Android Navigation
feedback_items.why_it_matters: Without a navigation structure, users are trapped on a single screen with no way to explore the app. A standard Bottom Navigation Bar provides immediate context and movement.
what_to_do: Add a BottomNavigationView for top-level app destinations
Include 3-5 clearly labeled menu items with icons (e.g., Home, Search, Profile)
Ensure the 'Back' button behavior follows Android platform standards
Highlight the active icon to show the user's current location

code_example.description: Define a BottomNavigationView in your layout

feedback_items.wireframe_changes: Add a Bottom Navigation Bar at the base of the screen with three icons: 'Home', 'Activity', and 'Settings'.

feedback_items.title: Add High-Visibility Interactive Elements
feedback_items.why_it_matters: Users rely on visual cues like buttons and cards to understand what is interactive. A lack of these elements forces users to guess where to tap, leading to a poor experience.
what_to_do: Add Material Design 'Cards' for content items to provide elevation and tap visual cues
Include a Floating Action Button (FAB) for the primary screen action
Use distinct text styles for headers vs. body text to create visual hierarchy
Add icons next to text labels to aid rapid recognition

code_example.description: Create a Material Card with a clear tap target
code_example.code:
<com.google.android.material.card.MaterialCardView
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:clickable="true"
    android:focusable="true"
    app:cardElevation="2dp"
    app:cardCornerRadius="8dp">

    <TextView
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:text="Start New Task"
        android:padding="16dp" />
</com.google.android.material.card.MaterialCardView>

feedback_items.wireframe_changes: Place a large 'Primary Action' button (FAB) in the bottom-right corner and populate the screen with a few card-based items containing icons.

feedback_items.title: Optimize Touch Target Sizes
feedback_items.why_it_matters: Small or non-existent touch targets make an app feel broken or difficult to use, especially for users with motor impairments or those using the app on the go.
what_to_do: Ensure all clickable elements are at least 48x48dp in size
Add padding to small icons to increase their touchable area without changing visual size
Space interactive elements at least 8dp apart to prevent accidental taps
Apply 'ripple' effects to give visual feedback when a target is touched

code_example.code:
<!-- Button with min height to meet accessibility standards -->
<Button
    android:id="@+id/submit_button"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:minHeight="48dp"
    android:text="Submit" />

feedback_items.wireframe_changes: Adjust all list items and buttons to ensure they have a visible height of at least 48dp and appropriate spacing.

feedback_items.title: Introduce Welcome and Onboarding Guidance
feedback_items.why_it_matters: New users need to understand the app's value and how to start. Guidance reduces the cognitive load of learning a new interface from scratch.
what_to_do: Add a 'Welcome' header or banner on the home screen
Implement a simple empty-state illustration with a 'Get Started' button
Use Tooltips or 'Tap Targets' to highlight key features for first-time users
Provide a clear 'Help' or 'Settings' icon in the top right
feedback_items.wireframe_changes: Add a 'Getting Started' card at the top of the layout with a brief description of the app's main function.

wireframe_instructions.overall_changes: Transform the current empty screen into a standard Android Dashboard layout featuring a Top App Bar, a scrollable content area with cards, and a Bottom Navigation Bar.
priority_fixes: Add a Top App Bar with a title 'My Dashboard'
Insert a Bottom Navigation Bar with 3 icons
Place a Floating Action Button in the bottom right corner
layout_modifications: Use a vertical LinearLayout or ConstraintLayout to stack content
Ensure margins of 16dp on the left and right of all content cards
color_adjustments: Use Material Surface color for the background
Apply a Primary color (e.g., #6200EE) to the FAB and App Bar
typography_changes: Use Headline6 for the App Bar title
Use Body1 for card content and Button text for actions
